This is a very important event in history of science.

Eratosthenes lived in Alexandria, in Egypt. And it was generally known that once a year way south in Siena (now it's called Aswan) things have no shadows. Just a curious thing like that.

Except for Eratosthenes. He thought, "In Siena things have no shadows at the same time when in Alexandria they have shadows. What does this mean? It means that the earth is not flat. So let's assume it's round."

From there he made a simple experiment. At the right day and time he had a pole stuck in the ground, and measured its shadow. Now he knew the length of the pole, the length of the shadow, and the distance from Alexandria to Siena. From these he computed the radius of the Earth.

And he got it right!

Eratosthenes was a genius.

Slight correction (see 2:22 - 2:32)
"Summer Solstice" and "Winter Solstice" are dependent on which hemisphere you're in, of course.
In the Northern Hemisphere, the Winter Solstice happens around December 21 and the Summer Solstice happens around June 21.
In the Southern Hemisphere, the Winter Solstice happens around June 21 and the Summer Solstice happens around December 21.
So, Solar Noon only happens in the Summer Solstice of the hemisphere you're in. You would never personally experience Solar Noon on the Winter Solstice, not counting watching it live on YouTube or something.

Refers to December at southern-latitude tropical boundary as containing a "winter" solstice. Not filmed from there, so I'll put it to not thinking through that line completely. Even then, it's a mistake. Also wrong is the twice-a-year line in the case that—on the Tropic (either end of the zone)—, this technically corresponds to a boundary where Lāhainā Noon is once, and it is on summer solstice for that particular Tropic.

Being super exact, that latitude is technically only capable of meeting that definition at a single point. As the Earth reaches the position of solstice in its orbit on a given year, there will be a particular point on that Tropic latitude that is, in fact, "facing the sun" (sun perpendicular to horizon if we ignore terrain features and elongated equatorial diameter). The rest of the points along this line (Tropic) miss it, and the one Lāhainā Noon, very technically, only falls slightly Within the Tropics if on the same side of the earth (That Year); whereas they get two on consecutive days at the night-side spot exactly equivalent, Mod 180°, in longitude but of slightly less latitude from the points perpendicular to the sun. For all the other longitudes in nighttime during that solstice, the Lāhainā Noon comes effectively twice per 6 months, two in the Northern Hemisphere and, alternately, a pair in the Southern, but the latitude is differentially lowered depending on how many hours' offset there is between noon and the solstice going forward vs. backward the periods I shall call super-supplementary (adding up to a full revolution of earth).

By that restricted, full-on-frictionless-vacuum metric, a funny thing is true: in about 183 days, the sun-earth axis spirals out a path of these perfectly high noons up and down the summertime half of the tropics, but the latitude experiencing them has an analog point, not line, actually facing and giving it a high noon which is perfectly high. Since a point cannot be tiled to cover a surface, you could wait an arbitrary amount of time, and the area receiving Lāhainā Noon (tropics) would never be perfectly covered as to having even one at each point.

Well it’s true that the subsolar point occurs twice a year between the tropics, the closer you are to the Tropics of Cancer or Capricorn, the closer those two dates merge. So near the June solstice those two dates could be June 20th and June 22nd, for example. Near the December solstice those two dates could be December 20th and 22nd, for example. The closer you are to the equator, the further those dates separate, becoming six months apart at the equator and occurring on the 2 equinoxes.The only place in the tropics that the sub solar point occur once a year is exactly at the Tropics of Cancer and Capricorn. Why is the longest day of the year not the hottest day of the year? Because the earth (and the atmosphere, and the oceans, etc) stores heat energy, and releases it rather slowly. So there's a propagation delay. And if there are winds aloft (jetstream, etc) this further confuses things, because they carry that released (radiated) heat energy to other places. So the hottest day of the year will be different, depending on where you live.

Way late to this game but I'll play anyway. The hottest day of the year doesn't match because of something, I can't recall the correct term but it is in effect temperature or climate lag. It's the same reason 12pm is not the hottest part of the day. The hottest part is ~2pm as the temperature lags behind the causes. It's a few hours in a day and in a season, it's several weeks.

It works both ways too. The coldest day of the year will be several weeks behind the shortest day of the year.

It also works on longer, climate scale levels. The warmest climate will lag months or even years behind the events which caused the warming.

"Why isn't the longest day of the year also the hottest day of the year." Simple. It's the difference between slopes and levels. On average, the longest day of the year will be the day that the temperature increases the most. But the next day will be almost as long, so the expected temp increase will be almost as significant. The hottest day won't come until the slope zeroes out and cooling begins.

I remember being a little confused by your aside question when I first came across it in 1989:
"Why doesn't the hottest day of the year match the longest day of the year?" The answer is pretty complex. It took a few years to fully understand the concept.
I seem to recall that it has something to do with the difference between net incoming solar radiation and net outgoing infrared radiation. For the atmosphere to cool down, the amount of outgoing IR radiation needs to surpass the amount of incoming solar radiation. During the spring and summer months, from late March until late September the sun is in the sky longer. So there is more daylight. However, just because there is more daylight does not mean that the incoming solar radiation will surpass the outgoing IR radiation. It is only during that period of time, between mid May and mid August, when the angle of the sun increases to a point where incoming solar radiation will outpace outgoing IR radiation, that the atmosphere will start to heat up more than it cools down. As long as the net amount of incoming radiation surpasses the net amount of outgoing radiation, the atmosphere will continue to heat up...even beyond the summer solstice, which is the longest day of the year.

A rather fun experiment is to have two identical sticks stuck into a board. The sticks must be the exact same length and be perfectly vertical. A friend takes one stick to the north say several hundred or better yet, several thousand miles. On the same day measure the length of the shadow when the sun is directly overhead. If you know the distance north between the two sticks and the length of the two shadows, you can calculate the size of the Earth.

Now a flat Earth person could argue that the difference is because the sun is closer than we think. In part 2, one stick is on a tall mountain and the other is at the base of the mountain. If the sun is very close, there would be a clear difference in the shadows that should match the calculated distance of the sun. (Assuming we have a flat Earth and a close sun.)

The reason why the longest day of the year is not the hottest day of the year is complicated, but to simplify it, it is because even though the days are getting shorter you are still adding more heat during the day than is escaping at night. (Daytime is significantly longer than nighttime.) On average, the equilibrium point happens about five to six weeks after the solstice. (That is also why the shortest day of the year is not the coldest.)

In regard to no shadows when sun is directly overhead, . . . . . i am a pilot of general aviation airplanes and i noticed that as i am climbing away from the earth (gaining altitude), the shadow of the airplane below on the earth's surface changes into a bright spot moving across the ground. Why? It's because i (the observer) am directly between the sun and that spot on the earth. In fact i am high enough that the silhouette of the airplane has become so small (as viewed from the ground) that the sun completely encircles it. Thus there is a place on the ground which used to be the plane's shadow at a lower altitude that has become a spot with no shadow because i am where the sun is in the sky.
If you were to write a child's short story about the Sun as an all powerful entity, you could point out that there is one thing the Sun cannot do which adds interesting texture to everything that we mere mortal observe . . . . the Sun cannot 'see' any shadows as it is the source of illumination.

Lahaina noon always happens exactly at local noon, which will only be noon on your timepiece if you happen to be on the defining meridian of the time zone you're in. Local noon occurs halfway between sunrise and sunset where you are one hour later than someone who is standing 15° east of you. But if you are standing just barely west of the Central time zone, then local noon will many minutes before your watch (remember watches?) chimes noon Mountain Time. Ideally, it would be 30 minutes, but the borders get manipulated to follow borders.

What's also interesting is that for every degree of latitude you get away from the tropics, the lower the sun will be at the summer solstice (and every other day of the year too). For examle I'm at 52 degrees north, which is roughly 29 degrees away from the tropic of cancer at 23 degrees north. At 23 degrees north the sun would be overhead, or at 90 degrees, on the summer solstice. So at 52 degrees north, the sun is 90-29=61 degrees in the sky on the summer solstice. New York, which is roughly 41 degrees north, would see the sun at 90-(41-23)=72 degrees.

Also the geographic north pole, at 90 degrees north, would see the sun at 90-(90-23)=23 degrees on the summer solstice. This explains why the poles are characteristically so much colder than the tropics, because the sun reaches them at a much lower angle.

Living ON either of the Tropic lines will give you this effect only once per year if you also happen to live at the precise longitude when the sun reaches its absolute highest latitude, and your hemisphere's summer season kicks off. Living closer to the equator, by mere degrees of latitude, and it happens twice per year. The shortest gap between Lahaina Noons grows exponentially the closer you get to the equator; from blink-and-you'll-miss-it at the Tropic line to a perfect half-year at the equator.

Another interesting fact, because our off-center elliptical orbit and the tilt of the axis, and our imperfect 365.25 day calendar, (some wobble, blah, blah, blah) the time of day for your two Lahaina Noons will also vary by greater and greater amounts the closer you are to the equator.

If you're in a jet going ~1000mph and maintaining a precise latitude a few seconds below a Tropic line, you can intersect Lahaina Noon twice in the same day. You'd be intersecting the analemma at one of the shortest distances you can make across it.

This phenomina is how Eratosthenese calculated the diameter of the earth. There was a famous well where on certain days of the year you could see to the bottom (in the Aswan area of Egypt). A few hundred miles directly North in Alexandrea (where he spent a lot of time) there was also a well that was almost exactly the same in diameter and depth. He reasoned that the angle of the shadow and distance could be used to calculate the circumference of the earth and came up with an answer that was remarkably close. IE about 10% out which was better than most of the estimates and calculations from the middle ages.

The longest day off the year is not the hottest for the same reason that solar noon isn't the hottest time of the day.  Even after the sun is highest, there is still plenty of solar energy comes in that exceeds the loss of energy through radiative cooling.  So the hottest time of the year is actually about a month after the Solstice
